prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Eddie Fender
Description: A student working part-time at the offices of Edgeworth and Co. Studying to be an attorney.
Character 1
Name: Samson Tangaroa
Description: My client, and a man said to be the greatest confectioner of his generation.
Character 2
Name: Artie Frost
Description: The murder victim. Found dead inside Samson Tangaroa's chocolate work.
Character 3
Name: Judy Bound
Description: Assistant to Samson Tangaroa. She's fond of the work of sculptor Paul Halique.
Character 4
Name: Tyrell Badd
Description: The detective assigned to this case. A man of few words.
Character 5
Name: Carmelo Gusto
Description: A candy-crafting confectioner who's taking part in the contest.
Character 6
Name: Delicia Scone
Description: A confectioner who will do whatever it takes to achieve her goals.
Character 7
Name: Manfred von Karma
Description: The prosecutor in charge of this case. It is said that he has never lost a trial in these past 25 years.
Character 8
Name: Laurice Deauxnim
Description: Pseudonym of Larry Butz, my friend since childhood. He fancies himself as something of an artist.
Character 9
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective from the local precinct who's always first on the scene at any murder investigation.
Character 10
Name: Kay Faraday
Description: A self-styled Great Thief and so-called "second Yatagarasu" who's always looking to bag the greatest treasure of all -- the truth.
Character 11
Name: Verity Gavèlle
Description: A district court judge and member of the Committee for Prosecutorial Excellence, who also acts as its mouthpiece.
Character 12
Name: Eustace Winner
Description: The greatest prosecutor ever to prosecute... according to himself, anyway. In actual fact, his relationship with logic is tenuous at best.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. Polishing it every day has become just another part of my daily routine.
Evidence 1
Name: Seal
Description: A seal that was found near the body when it was discovered. What could the design signify?
Evidence 2
Name: Crime Scene Notes
Description: Notes about the crime scene. The police have taken custody of the body. [info] The victim's body found in Samson Tangaroa's room, inside a chocolate treasure chest. The cause of death appears to have been blood loss following blunt force trauma. [caption] The victim's body is curled inside a chest crushed by a ship post. The body is half covered by a blue sheet. There is a silver coin next to the body.
Evidence 3
Name: Mr. Tangaroa's Teapot
Description: A Paul Halique piece with Tangaroa's fingerprints on it.
Evidence 4
Name: Contest Rules
Description: A piece of paper listing the rules for the contest.
Evidence 5
Name: Frame Finger Marks
Description: Someone left finger marks on the chocolate frame, but didn't leave any prints.
Evidence 6
Name: Mansion Key
Description: The one and only key that unlocks every door in the mansion. Tangaroa was in possession of it the entire time.
Evidence 7
Name: Salt Lamp
Description: Salt lamp found in Scone's room. Stained with the victim's blood.
Evidence 8
Name: Fake Confections
Description: Ms. Scone's so-called creations were all fake plastic models, covered in a thick layer of whipped cream.
Evidence 9
Name: Chocolates
Description: Tangaroa's favorite, handmade by Bound. Rather misshapened, and incredibly sweet.
Evidence 10
Name: Instant Camera
Description: Takes photos that develop instantly. A new film cartridge has twenty exposures, but there are only three remaining.
Evidence 11
Name: Mr. Frost's Room
Description: A photo of Frost's sculptures, taken by Judy Bound. Two photos, one from Bound and one from Detective Badd.
Evidence 12
Name: Ms. Scone's Statement
Description: Frost's sculptures were "scrumptious", except for the lyre, which was salty.
Evidence 13
Name: Semifinal Entries
Description: Frost's and Gusto's creations had different designs, but tasted the same.
Evidence 14
Name: Ultimate Cookbook
Description: A book containing formulas for creating a cure for taste disorders and other chemical and pharmaceutical items.
Evidence 15
Name: Victim's Blood
Description: Frost's blood was found in the fountain, but not at the scene of the crime.
Evidence 16
Name: Family Photo
Description: A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal.
Evidence 17
Name: Prosecutor's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. However, I prefer to keep it in my pocket.
Evidence 18
Name: IS-7 Incident Case File
Description: Documents providing an overview of the IS-7 Incident. Documents received from Fender, including his comments in red.
Evidence 19
Name: Gallery Pamphlet
Description: A pamphlet received upon entry to the gallery.
Evidence 20
Name: Winter Wing Photo
Description: Statues matching those made by the victim eighteen years ago.
Evidence 21
Name: Pisces Statue Sketch
Description: A sketch by Larry depicting the Pisces statue exactly as he saw it.
Evidence 22
Name: Used Blowtorch
Description: There are signs it was used just before the police arrived. Possibly to heat something?
Evidence 23
Name: Luminous Cloth
Description: Cloth that glows when connected to a full-spectrum light-emitting device. [caption] Looks like a blue sheet. Delicia Scone's property. One of these was lost eighteen years ago. Given to Bound by Scone. Lost eighteen years ago, only to be rediscovered floating in the fountain.
Evidence 24
Name: Poison Gas Ingredients
Description: The gas was produced when bright red Ubiquium and pure white Asphyxion were mixed together.
Evidence 25
Name: Ultimate Cookbook
Description: A book containing formulas for creating a cure for taste disorders and other chemical and pharmaceutical items.
Evidence 26
Name: Frame Finger Marks
Description: Finger marks left by someone in Tangaroa's room. No accompanying prints.
Evidence 27
Name: Salt Lamp
Description: A photograph of the murder weapon from the IS-7 Incident. It's a salt lamp stained with Frost's blood.
Evidence 28
Name: Family Photo
Description: A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal.
Evidence 29
Name: Teapot
Description: Designed by Paul Halique. One of Judy Bound's prize possessions.
Evidence 30
Name: Ceramic Fragment
Description: Found in a puddle of tea. The design looks familiar.
Evidence 31
Name: Lift Cart
Description: Used by Frost to transport ice eighteen years ago. The top of the platform is wet.
Evidence 32
Name: Larry's Sketches
Description: Sketches depicting exactly what Larry saw.
Evidence 33
Name: Gemini Case Analysis Results
Description: Results of the analysis conducted on the melted contents of the Gemini case.
Evidence 34
Name: Chocolates
Description: Handmade by Bound. Slightly melted after being kept in her pocket.
Evidence 35
Name: Statute of Limitations
Description: A book explaining the statutes of limitations of various crimes.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: If the body had been found in a locked room... Master would've been the prime suspect.
Person: Badd
Testimony 1
Testimony: That's why Master made sure to leave the door to his own room unlocked...
Person: Badd
Testimony 2
Testimony: And to ensure that the body would be seen... Master broke the lid on the treasure chest.
Person: Badd
Testimony 3
Testimony: After the judging... everyone was scheduled to meet in Master's room...
Person: Badd
Testimony 4
Testimony: That would have created the impression... that the murder had occurred... while he was away.
Person: Badd

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's see. I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. The user provided a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies. Let me go through them step by step.

First, looking at the testimonies. Testimony 0 to 4 are all from Badd. Testimony 3 says: "After the judging... everyone was scheduled to meet in Master's room..." So the plan was that after the judging, everyone would meet in Samson Tangaroa's room. Testimony 2 mentions that Master broke the lid on the treasure chest to ensure the body would be seen. Testimony 1 states that Master left his door unlocked to avoid being the prime suspect if the body was found in a locked room.

Now, looking at the evidences. Evidence 2 is the Crime Scene Notes. It mentions that the victim's body was found in Samson Tangaroa's room, inside a chocolate treasure chest. The cause was blunt force trauma. The notes also say the body is in a chest crushed by a ship post, with a blue sheet and a silver coin nearby.

Wait, Testimony 3 says everyone was scheduled to meet in Master's room after judging. But according to the crime scene notes (Evidence 2), the body was found in Master's room. If everyone was supposed to meet there, then the murder must have occurred before the meeting. But according to Testimony 4, the idea was to make it seem like the murder happened while Master was away. But if the body is in his room where the meeting was supposed to take place, that might contradict something. Let me check the timeline.

If the meeting was scheduled in Master's room after judging, then Master would be present there during the meeting. If the body was found in his room, which was supposed to be unlocked (Testimony 1), then the implication is that the murder happened when he wasn't there. But if everyone was coming to his room, how could he be away? Unless he wasn't in the room when the murder happened. But the key point is Testimony 3 says the meeting was scheduled in Master's room. So the plan was to have people come there, but the body is already there. Wait, but the murder would have to happen before the meeting. So the idea is that Master left the room unlocked, broke the chest lid so the body is visible, and when people come for the meeting, they find the body. But if the body was found in his room, which is where everyone was supposed to meet, then the murder must have occurred there before the meeting. But Testimony 4 says the plan was to make it seem like the murder happened while he was away. But if he was supposed to be in his room for the meeting, then how could he be away? Unless he was not present when the murder occurred, but the meeting was in his room. Hmm, maybe the contradiction is between the location of the body and the testimony about where the meeting was supposed to be. 

Wait, Evidence 2 says the body was found in Samson's room. Testimony 3 says the meeting was scheduled there. So if the body was in the room where the meeting was to take place, and the murder was supposed to happen while he was away, but the meeting would have him present. So perhaps the contradiction is that if the meeting was in his room, he would be there, so he couldn't have been away when the murder happened. But according to Testimony 4, the plan was to create the impression that the murder occurred while he was away. But if the meeting was in his room, he would have been present, so the alibi wouldn't hold. Therefore, Testimony 3 (meeting scheduled in Master's room) and Evidence 2 (body found in Master's room) would contradict the alibi. Wait, but how does that directly contradict the testimony?

Alternatively, looking at Evidence 6: Mansion Key. It says Samson had the only key, which he kept the entire time. If the door was supposed to be unlocked (Testimony 1), but the key was in his possession, then he could have locked it if he wanted. But Testimony 1 says he left it unlocked to avoid being a suspect in a locked room. But Evidence 6 shows he had the key, which supports that he could lock or unlock the room. Not sure if that's a contradiction here.

Another angle: Testimony 2 says Master broke the lid on the treasure chest to ensure the body would be seen. But Evidence 2 describes the body as being inside the chest, which was crushed by a ship post, and the lid being broken would make it visible. That seems consistent.

Wait, let's look at Testimony 3 and Evidence 6. Testimony 3 says everyone was scheduled to meet in Master's room after judging. Evidence 6 says the mansion key was in Tangaroa's possession the entire time. If the key is needed to unlock the rooms, and he had the only key, then how could others enter his room unless he unlocked it. But Testimony 1 says he left his door unlocked. So that aligns with Evidence 6, because he used the key to leave it unlocked. So no contradiction there.

Hmm. Let's think again. The key contradiction would be if a testimony claims the room was locked, but evidence says it was unlocked, but that's not the case here.

Wait, perhaps looking at Testimony 3 and Evidence 2. Testimony 3 states that after the judging, everyone was to meet in Master's room. But Evidence 2 says the body was found in Master's room. If the meeting was scheduled there, then the body would be discovered during the meeting. But according to the testimonies, the plan was to make it seem like the murder occurred while Master was away. But if the meeting is in his room, then he would be present during the meeting, so the murder would have to have happened before he arrived. But if the body is in his room, which he was supposed to be in during the meeting, then how could he have been away? This creates a contradiction. Because if the body is in his room, which was the scheduled meeting place, then the murder would have to occur there before the meeting, but Master would have to have been there to commit the murder and then leave the door unlocked. But the alibi is supposed to be that he was away. Therefore, the presence of the body in his own room contradicts the idea that the murder happened while he was away. Because the meeting was in his room, he would be expected to be there, so if the murder happened there, he would have been present. Therefore, Testimony 4 (murder occurred while he was away) is contradicted by Evidence 2 (body found in his room where the meeting was scheduled). But Testimony 3 is about the meeting being scheduled there. So the contradiction is between Testimony 3 (meeting in Master's room) and Evidence 2 (body found there), which would mean that the meeting would have found the body, but how does that create an alibi? Maybe the plan was to have the meeting in Master's room, implying that he was there, but the body being found there would make him the prime suspect. But according to Testimony 0, if the body was found in a locked room, Master would be the prime suspect, so he left it unlocked. But then Testimony 3 and 4 suggest the plan was to have the murder occur while he was away. Wait, perhaps the contradiction is that if the meeting was in Master's room, then the body being there would mean he was present when the murder happened. But the testimonies say that the plan was to make it seem like the murder happened while he was away. Therefore, the fact that the body is in his own room contradicts the alibi of him being away. Therefore, Evidence 2 (body in his room) and Testimony 4 (murder occurred while he was away) contradict each other. Alternatively, Testimony 3 says the meeting was scheduled in his room, so he would be there, making the alibi impossible. Therefore, the contradiction is between Testimony 3 and Evidence 2. But I need to check exactly.

Alternatively, looking at Evidence 6 (Mansion Key) and Testimony 1 (Master left the door unlocked). Evidence 6 says he had the key the entire time, which would allow him to lock or unlock the doors. So if he left his door unlocked, that's possible. So no contradiction there.

Another angle: Evidence 23 is Luminous Cloth, which is a blue sheet. The crime scene notes (Evidence 2) mention a blue sheet covering half the body. Evidence 23 says the cloth is Delicia Scone's property, lost 18 years ago, and found in the fountain. But the crime scene has a blue sheet. So the blue sheet at the crime scene is Scone's. This could link her to the crime scene. But how does this relate to testimonies?

Alternatively, Testimony 2 says Master broke the lid on the treasure chest to ensure the body would be seen. Evidence 2's crime scene notes mention the body is inside a chocolate treasure chest. If the lid was broken, that's consistent. Not a contradiction.

Wait, maybe Testimony 3 and Evidence 6. Testimony 3 says everyone was scheduled to meet in Master's room. If the only key is with Master (Evidence 6), then he must have unlocked the room for the meeting. But Testimony 1 says he left the door unlocked. So that's possible. No contradiction.

Wait, perhaps Testimony 3 (meeting scheduled in Master's room) and Evidence 2 (body found in Master's room). If the meeting was supposed to take place there, then the body would have been discovered during the meeting, which would mean that the murder happened before the meeting. But the plan according to Testimony 4 is to create the impression that the murder occurred while he was away. But if the meeting was in his room, he would have been present during the meeting, implying he was there. Therefore, the murder occurring in his room while he was supposed to be there (since the meeting was there) contradicts the alibi that he was away. Therefore, the presence of the body in his room (Evidence 2) contradicts Testimony 4, which claims the plan was to make it look like the murder happened while he was away. So the contradiction is between Evidence 2 and Testimony 4.

But how does that fit? Let me check the exact wording. Testimony 4: "That would have created the impression... that the murder had occurred... while he was away." So the idea is that by leaving the door unlocked and the body visible, people would think the murder happened when he wasn't there. But if the body is in his own room, and the meeting was there, then the murder must have occurred in his room. If the meeting was supposed to happen there, then he would have been present, so the alibi that he was away doesn't hold. Therefore, Evidence 2 (body in his room) and Testimony 4 (impression murder happened while he was away) contradict each other. But I need to check which specific evidence and testimony numbers.

Evidence 2 is the Crime Scene Notes, which state the body was found in Samson's room. Testimony 4 is the one about creating the impression the murder occurred while he was away. So the contradiction is that if the body was found in his room, and the meeting was scheduled there (Testimony 3), then the alibi of being away doesn't make sense. But the key contradiction is between the body's location and the alibi's implication. Therefore, the pair would be Evidence 2 and Testimony 4.

Wait, but the user asks for evidence and testimony that contradict each other. So if Testimony 4 says the plan was to make it seem like the murder happened while he was away, but Evidence 2 places the body in his room, then the contradiction is that if the murder occurred in his room, he would have been present, thus contradicting the alibi. Therefore, the evidence and testimony that contradict each other are Evidence 2 (body in his room) and Testimony 4 (alibi of being away). Therefore, {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 4}.

But let me double-check. Testimony 4: "That would have created the impression... that the murder had occurred... while he was away." So the plan is to make people think the murder happened when he wasn't in his room. But if the murder happened in his room, then logically he would have been there, unless he wasn't. But if the body is found in his room, and he claims to have been away, then the contradiction arises. Therefore, the evidence (body in his room) contradicts the testimony that the murder was supposed to look like it happened while he was away. Therefore, Evidence 2 and Testimony 4.

Person: von Karma
Testimony 1

Person: von Karma
Testimony 2
Testimony: If he had left the murder weapon at the crime scene, Master would have been the one suspected.
Person: von Karma
Testimony 3
Testimony: He couldn't move the body, but it was easy to move the murder weapon.
Person: von Karma
Testimony 4
Testimony: Ergo, there would be no evidence pointing to a specific culprit at the crime scene.
Person: von Karma

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's see. I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. The user wants one pair. Let's start by going through the testimonies and checking the evidences.

Testimony 0 is von Karma saying that the master (probably Samson Tangaroa) used the salt lamp to kill the victim. Then Testimony 1 says the murder weapon was placed in Delicia's room. The relevant evidence here would be Evidence 7, the Salt Lamp found in Scone's room with the victim's blood. That seems to support the testimony. But maybe there's a contradiction elsewhere.

Looking at Testimony 3: "He couldn't move the body, but it was easy to move the murder weapon." So von Karma is arguing that the murderer moved the weapon to Scone's room. But if the murder happened in Tangaroa's room (as per Evidence 2, the crime scene notes), and the body was found there, then the blood from the victim would be at the crime scene. However, Evidence 15 says the victim's blood was found in the fountain, not at the crime scene. Wait, the body was found in Tangaroa's chocolate work, and the cause was blunt force trauma leading to blood loss. But the blood isn't at the scene. That might be a contradiction. If the murder happened there, why is the blood in the fountain?

But how does that relate to Testimony 3? Testimony 3 says he couldn't move the body. But if the blood is in the fountain, maybe the murder happened elsewhere, which would contradict the crime scene notes. Wait, Evidence 15 states: "Frost's blood was found in the fountain, but not at the scene of the crime." So the murder scene (Tangaroa's room) has no blood, but the fountain does. That suggests the murder didn't happen there. So if the body was moved, but Testimony 3 says he couldn't move the body. So there's a contradiction here. Because if the body was found in Tangaroa's room but the blood is in the fountain, then the body was moved from the fountain to Tangaroa's room. But von Karma's testimony says the murderer couldn't move the body. That would mean the body should be where the murder happened. But the blood isn't there, so the body must have been moved. Therefore, Testimony 3 (claiming the body couldn't be moved) contradicts Evidence 15 (blood elsewhere, implying the body was moved). So the evidence 15 and testimony 3 contradict each other.

Alternatively, Evidence 2 (crime scene notes) says the body was found in Tangaroa's room, and the cause was blood loss from blunt trauma. But Evidence 15 says the blood wasn't there, but in the fountain. So the actual murder occurred at the fountain, and the body was moved. But Testimony 3 says the murderer couldn't move the body. So moving the body would contradict Testimony 3. Therefore, Evidence 15 (blood in fountain) and Testimony 3 (couldn't move body) contradict each other. The body must have been moved, but the testimony says it wasn't possible. Therefore, the contradiction is between Evidence 15 and Testimony 3.

Wait, but Testimony 3 says "He couldn't move the body, but it was easy to move the murder weapon." So if the body couldn't be moved, but the blood is in the fountain, that suggests the murder happened at the fountain. Therefore, the body was moved from the fountain to the crime scene (Tangaroa's room). So von Karma's testimony that the body couldn't be moved is contradicted by the presence of blood elsewhere, implying the body was moved. Hence, Evidence 15 contradicts Testimony 3.

Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective from the local precinct who's always first on the scene at any murder investigation.
Character 10
Name: Kay Faraday
Description: A self-styled Great Thief and so-called "second Yatagarasu" who's always looking to bag the greatest treasure of all -- the truth.
Character 11
Name: Verity Gavèlle
Description: A district court judge and member of the Committee for Prosecutorial Excellence, who also acts as its mouthpiece.
Character 12
Name: Eustace Winner
Description: The greatest prosecutor ever to prosecute... according to himself, anyway. In actual fact, his relationship with logic is tenuous at best.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. Polishing it every day has become just another part of my daily routine.
Evidence 1
Name: Seal
Description: A seal that was found near the body when it was discovered. What could the design signify?
Evidence 2
Name: Crime Scene Notes
Description: Notes about the crime scene. The police have taken custody of the body. [info] The victim's body found in Samson Tangaroa's room, inside a chocolate treasure chest. The cause of death appears to have been blood loss following blunt force trauma. [caption] The victim's body is curled inside a chest crushed by a ship post. The body is half covered by a blue sheet. There is a silver coin next to the body.
Evidence 3
Name: Mr. Tangaroa's Teapot
Description: A Paul Halique piece with Tangaroa's fingerprints on it.
Evidence 4
Name: Contest Rules
Description: A piece of paper listing the rules for the contest.
Evidence 5
Name: Frame Finger Marks
Description: Someone left finger marks on the chocolate frame, but didn't leave any prints.
Evidence 6
Name: Mansion Key
Description: The one and only key that unlocks every door in the mansion. Tangaroa was in possession of it the entire time.
Evidence 7
Name: Salt Lamp
Description: Salt lamp found in Scone's room. Stained with the victim's blood.
Evidence 8
Name: Fake Confections
Description: Ms. Scone's so-called creations were all fake plastic models, covered in a thick layer of whipped cream.
Evidence 9
Name: Chocolates
Description: Tangaroa's favorite, handmade by Bound. Rather misshapened, and incredibly sweet.
Evidence 10
Name: Instant Camera
Description: Takes photos that develop instantly. A new film cartridge has twenty exposures, but there are only three remaining.
Evidence 11
Name: Mr. Frost's Room
Description: A photo of Frost's sculptures, taken by Judy Bound. Two photos, one from Bound and one from Detective Badd.
Evidence 12
Name: Ms. Scone's Statement
Description: Frost's sculptures were "scrumptious", except for the lyre, which was salty.
Evidence 13
Name: Semifinal Entries
Description: Frost's and Gusto's creations had different designs, but tasted the same.
Evidence 14
Name: Ultimate Cookbook
Description: A book containing formulas for creating a cure for taste disorders and other chemical and pharmaceutical items.
Evidence 15
Name: Victim's Blood
Description: Frost's blood was found in the fountain, but not at the scene of the crime.
Evidence 16
Name: Family Photo
Description: A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal.
Evidence 17
Name: Prosecutor's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. However, I prefer to keep it in my pocket.
Evidence 18
Name: IS-7 Incident Case File
Description: Documents providing an overview of the IS-7 Incident. Documents received from Fender, including his comments in red.
Evidence 19
Name: Gallery Pamphlet
Description: A pamphlet received upon entry to the gallery.
Evidence 20
Name: Winter Wing Photo
Description: Statues matching those made by the victim eighteen years ago.
Evidence 21
Name: Pisces Statue Sketch
Description: A sketch by Larry depicting the Pisces statue exactly as he saw it.
Evidence 22
Name: Used Blowtorch
Description: There are signs it was used just before the police arrived. Possibly to heat something?
Evidence 23
Name: Luminous Cloth
Description: Cloth that glows when connected to a full-spectrum light-emitting device. [caption] Looks like a blue sheet. Delicia Scone's property. One of these was lost eighteen years ago. Given to Bound by Scone. Lost eighteen years ago, only to be rediscovered floating in the fountain.
Evidence 24
Name: Poison Gas Ingredients
Description: The gas was produced when bright red Ubiquium and pure white Asphyxion were mixed together.
Evidence 25
Name: Ultimate Cookbook
Description: A book containing formulas for creating a cure for taste disorders and other chemical and pharmaceutical items.
Evidence 26
Name: Frame Finger Marks
Description: Finger marks left by someone in Tangaroa's room. No accompanying prints.
Evidence 27
Name: Salt Lamp
Description: A photograph of the murder weapon from the IS-7 Incident. It's a salt lamp stained with Frost's blood.
Evidence 28
Name: Family Photo
Description: A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal.
Evidence 29
Name: Teapot
Description: Designed by Paul Halique. One of Judy Bound's prize possessions.
Evidence 30
Name: Ceramic Fragment
Description: Found in a puddle of tea. The design looks familiar.
Evidence 31
Name: Lift Cart
Description: Used by Frost to transport ice eighteen years ago. The top of the platform is wet.
Evidence 32
Name: Larry's Sketches
Description: Sketches depicting exactly what Larry saw.
Evidence 33
Name: Gemini Case Analysis Results
Description: Results of the analysis conducted on the melted contents of the Gemini case.
Evidence 34
Name: Chocolates
Description: Handmade by Bound. Slightly melted after being kept in her pocket.
Evidence 35
Name: Statute of Limitations
Description: A book explaining the statutes of limitations of various crimes.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: That artist was the "first" to discover the victim, so naturally he's the "best" suspect!
Person: Debeste
Testimony 1
Testimony: The poison gas was caused by Normallium, a chemical found in paint, right?
Person: Debeste
Testimony 2
Testimony: As he was carrying paint near the victim, he would've had the "best" chance.
Person: Debeste
Testimony 3
Testimony: The paint, along with being the first witness! ...That pretty much proves he's the culprit!
Person: Debeste

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, let's see. I need to find which evidence and testimony contradict each other. The testimonies are from Debeste, and there are four of them. The evidence list is quite extensive, so I should go through each testimony and check against the evidence.

Starting with Testimony 0: Debeste says the artist (probably Larry as Laurice Deauxnim) was the first to discover the victim, making him the best suspect. But looking at the evidence, maybe there's something about the crime scene. Evidence 2 mentions the body was found in Samson's chocolate work, and there's a seal near the body. Not sure how that contradicts yet.

Testimony 1 claims the poison gas was caused by Normallium in paint. But looking at the evidence, Evidence 24 states the gas was from mixing Ubiquium and Asphyxion. So that's a contradiction. Because the testimony says Normallium in paint, but evidence 24 says different chemicals. So Testimony 1 contradicts Evidence 24.

Wait, but I need to check the exact wording. Testimony 1 says "poison gas was caused by Normallium, a chemical found in paint". But Evidence 24: "gas produced when bright red Ubiquium and pure white Asphyxion were mixed". So the ingredients are different. Therefore, Testimony 1 is incorrect based on Evidence 24. So that's a contradiction between Testimony 1 and Evidence 24.

Another possibility: Testimony 3 says the paint and being first witness prove the culprit. But if the poison gas wasn't from paint (as per Evidence 24), then the basis of the testimony is wrong. So Testimony 1's claim about Normallium in paint causing the gas is contradicted by Evidence 24. Therefore, the pair would be Evidence 24 and Testimony 1. But wait, Evidence 24 is named "Poison Gas Ingredients" with the correct components. So yes, Testimony 1's statement about Normallium is contradicted by Evidence 24.

Looking at the evidence numbers, Evidence 24 is "Poison Gas Ingredients: The gas was produced when bright red Ubiquium and pure white Asphyxion were mixed together." So the testimony is wrong about the chemical involved. Therefore, the contradiction is between Testimony 1 and Evidence 24.
